description: From Middle English maker, makere, equivalent to make +‎ -er. Compare Scots makar, West Frisian makker, Dutch maker, German Macher, Danish mager, Swedish makare. Doublet of makar.

entries.meaning: Someone who makes; a person or thing that makes or produces something.
(usually capitalized and preceded by the) God.

examples: Set ſophia aſyde, for euery iack rakerAnd euery mad medler muſt now be a maker

entries.meaning: (law) Someone who signs a promissory note, thereby becoming responsible for payment.
